Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The temple holds a routine evening chant.
Story:
I scrolled through my messages, smiling at the one from my boyfriend: “Let’s have a date night this week! Any evening works for me.” My heart fluttered. We hadn’t had much time together lately, and I knew how much it meant to him—and to me—to reconnect, to laugh over dinner, to just be us. I started to type a reply, but then my phone buzzed again. This time, it was a reminder from the temple: “Evening chant every night this week. Your presence supports the sangha.”

I stared at the screen, feeling a knot tighten in my chest. The temple was my spiritual home, and the evening chants were more than routine—they were a commitment to my practice and my community. I knew the monks and my fellow practitioners counted on me, and I felt a deep responsibility not to let them down. But I also knew how much my boyfriend looked forward to our time together, how he’d been hoping for a special evening just for us. I wanted to be present for both, but the expectations pulled me in opposite directions, leaving me torn and anxious, unsure which part of myself to honor.
